This is partly resolved thanks to @jiajiechen and the tools scripts will be shipped along with the package starting from the next version. More work needs to be done to move these scripts into bin/ to make it easier to use.
0.9.5 pip packages have been released for a while and should have resolved this problem.
0.9.5 pip packages have been released for a while and should have resolved this problem.

In 0.9.3, installing cudnn was part of the instruction since there's no run-time detection for loading the .so. Starting from 0.9.5, cudnnv6 is statically linked and shipped as part of mxnet, so you don't need to install cudnn any more. 0.9.5 pip packages have been released for a while and should have resolved this problem.
If you use OpenCV2.4, change `-lopencv_imgcodecs` to `-lopencv_highgui` instead (and you will probably need to suffer through installing all the dependencies required by opencv UIs...)

@EvanzzzZ Thanks for the response! I think your guess is probably right, I use the following code to split LeNet into different modules:
```
def get_lenet_symbol(num_classes=10, add_stn=False):
    '''
    get lenet symbol, and split it into multiple modules wrt layers
    '''
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    if(add_stn):
        data = mx.sym.SpatialTransformer(data=data, loc=get_loc(data), target_shape = (28,28),
                                         transform_type="affine", sampler_type="bilinear")
    #module 1:------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # first conv
    conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(5,5), num_filter=20)
    tanh1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv1, act_type="tanh")
    pool1 = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=tanh1, pool_type="max",
                              kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2))
    mod1 = mx.mod.Module(pool1, label_names=[], context=mx.context.cpu())
    #module 2:------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # second conv
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    conv2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(5,5), num_filter=50)
    tanh2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv2, act_type="tanh")
    pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=tanh2, pool_type="max",
                              kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2))
    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool2)
    mod2 = mx.mod.Module(tanh2, label_names=[], context=mx.context.cpu())

    #module 3:------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # first fullc
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=500)
    tanh3 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc1, act_type="tanh")
    mod3 = mx.mod.Module(tanh3, label_names=[], context=mx.context.cpu())

    #module 4:------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # second fullc
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=num_classes)
    # loss
    lenet = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc2, name='softmax')
    mod4 = mx.mod.Module(lenet, context=mx.context.cpu())

    #--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # Container module
    #--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    lenet_mod_seq = mx.mod.SequentialModule()
    lenet_mod_seq.add(mod1, take_labels=False).add(mod2, auto_wiring=True, take_labels=False).add(mod3, auto_wiring=True, take_labels=False).add(mod4, take_labels=True, auto_wiring=True)
    return lenet_mod_seq
```
Based on my tests of time costs for each iteration and each epoch, after splitting the network, the time costs are slightly higher than just train using the original code (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_mnist.py). (e.g. 424.044 sec for each epoch after splitting, and 405 sec for each epoch on the original code, trained with MNIST data set using batch size of 128).
But, how can I totally make sure that this is the case (I don't need to explicitly change the input of the each module following the first module in the chain)?

You can set that in command line like 


what's the situation of fp16 support in mxnet

no it is not solved, we have ended up modifying storage.cc and making native storage manager a default. The threaded pooled one is garbage, never frees the memory making it impossible to use in any application where we need to be able to use DNN and cuda at the same time.
@lygstate inference or trainning acceleration on mobile or embed system device etc.
I means the progress of fp16 supportï¼Œ if it's not finished what I can do for itï¼Ÿ

In my case the Xcode gcc was used instead of the gcc installed by homebrew (which includes support for OpenMP), so I've just added this to the config.mk:

CC=gcc-7
CXX=gcc-7
SHLIB_OPENMP_CFLAGS=-fopenmp
SHLIB_OPENMP_CXXFLAGS=-fopenmp
SHLIB_OPENMP_FCFLAGS=-fopenmp
SHLIB_OPENMP_FFLAGS=-fopenmp

And so far it seems to work.

Another minor fix for building support for Scala, I have to edit the file:

mxnet/scala-package/macros/pom.xml

And replace ${platform} by osx-x86_64 and now the call to "make scalapkg" works.

IMPORTANT: all this "fixes" should be careful reviewed, these are only attempt to make mxnet work on my laptop.

the 0.9.5 version doesn't use your installed cudnnv4, but rather the statically linked cudnnv6 :)

It is because we take another way to implement kernel -- Kernel::Launch,
which is easier to understand than mshadow. You can see the detail in
src/operator/mxnet_op.h.
On Mon, May 22, 2560 at 14:47 EvanChong <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Trying to understand how to add new operators in mxnet,
>
> but got confused about relu defined in file elementwise_unary_op.h here
> <https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/tensor/elemwise_unary_op.h#L140>
> .
>
> Since mshadow_op.h already provide implementation of relu, see here
> <https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/mshadow_op.h#L73>.
>
> Why the elementwise operation need to recreate a relu structure and also
> include the index as params ,
> Rather than just using the one provided by mshadow_op ?
>
> Is this something "must do" with reregistering operator with nnvm or just
> duplicated code implemented.

There are methods `UnaryLaunch()` and `UnaryCompute()` in `elementwise_unary_op.h`, which 'UnaryLaunch()' use Kernel::Launch that you mentioned above while `UnaryCompute ` implement ops with mshadow, see [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/tensor/elemwise_unary_op.h#L56).

The code use UnaryCompute to implement a negation, which I think can also be implemented by using the  Kernel::Launch that you suggested. Is there any reason to make these two different launching methods?

Correct me if I'm wrong.
